newsitem.title: USA: FTC may expand tobacco inquiry beyond 'Joe Camel'.
newsitem.headline: FTC may expand tobacco inquiry beyond 'Joe Camel'.

text.p: Federal Trade Commission Chairman Robert Pitofsky said that a renewed investigation into R.J. Reynolds "Joe Camel" campaign may open the door to a broader investigation of tobacco advertising.

In an appearance on Court TV telecast over the weekend, Pitofsky said the FTC is investigating whether there is new evidence against the "Joe Camel" campaign, which critics assert attracts underage smokers.
He acknowledged the FTC is likely to investigate other tobacco campanies after it looks at the "Joe Camel" campaign.

"We've always cast our eye at other companies' advertising," Pitofsky said. "Our jurisdiction is to prevent advertising that's deceptive and unfair and that would be true of any product. This just happens to be one advertising campaign."
Pressed whether the FTC would look specifically at other tobacco company advertising so that it was not singling out R.J. Reynolds, Pitofsky said: "We would probably take a look at that as well."
A spokesman for the Tobacco Institute said Monday that Pitofsky's comment was the first he had heard that there might be such a broadened investigation.

"It's not an area we've had an opportunity to think about and discuss," said Walker Merryman of the tobacco company trade association. Merryman said he had no knowledge that the FTC had contacted any other companies.
In 1994, before Pitofsky came on board, the FTC voted 3-2 not to take action against the "Joe Camel" campaign but left the door open to future action.
Recently the FTC staff recommended examining the issue again, contending there was new evidence showing the "Joe Camel" campaign affects children.
Pitofsky said he wanted to hear both sides before he made up his mind.

"We haven't had a chance to have the Reynolds people in to give us their side of the story on what is claimed to be new evidence," he said. "Their assertion is that there's no connection between the campaign and consumption and certainly no connection between the campaign and consumption by underage smokers," he said. "And we'll just have to see what the facts are."
